ledVsMysore.title: Led Class vs Mysore Style
ledVsMysore.intro: Two ways to practice Ashtanga, both valuable.

led.title: Led Class
led.description: Everyone moves together following the teacher's count.
points: Usually offered once or twice a week

mysore.title: Mysore Style
mysore.description: You practice independently while the teacher guides you.

recommendation.title: Which should I start with?
recommendation.text: We recommend Mysore. You get personalised attention and can learn at your own pace, no pressure to keep up with experienced practitioners.

firstClass.title: Your first Mysore class
firstClass.intro: Walking into a Mysore room for the first time can feel intimidating. The room will likely be warm, humid, and filled with the sound of breath—this is normal. Here's exactly what to expect.

classSchedule.title: When do classes start?

textParts.before: Mysore classes typically start early, 6:00am, 6:30am, or sometimes 7:00 or 7:30am depending on the
textParts.after: . Some shalas offer multiple shifts, for example one at 6:30am and another at 8:30am. Classes usually run for about 2 hours.

classSchedule.arrivalNote: You can arrive at any point that gives you enough time to practice. If a class starts at 6:30am and runs until 8:30am, you could arrive anytime before roughly 7:50am to have about 40 minutes of practice.

steps.title: Arrive and introduce yourself
steps.text: When you arrive, find the teacher and make eye contact if they don't come straight to you. Introduce yourself, and let them know you're new. They will ask you a few questions about any injuries or previous yoga experience.

steps.title: Find your spot
steps.text: The teacher will help you find a place for your mat, or show you where to borrow one from the studio. Set up and wait, the teacher will soon be with you and it is completely normal to be "doing nothing" while you wait.

textParts.before: The teacher will guide you through the opening sequence, typically
textParts.after: A and B. They'll teach you the movements and breathing pattern, then ask you to repeat it a few times on your own while they watch and correct you.

textParts.before: Depending on how you're doing (both with what was just taught and your energy levels) the teacher might add a few more poses. There's no rush. Some days you might only learn

steps.title: Closing and rest
steps.text: When it's time to finish, the teacher will show you the closing sequence, which are the last three poses. Then you must rest. We always rest after practice; it helps the body absorb what you've done.

textParts.before: At some point during the class, the teacher may call everyone to stand in
textParts.after: for the opening mantra. This is a call-and-response chant, the teacher says a line and students repeat. Don't worry if you don't know the words, just stand respectfully and listen.

duration.title: How long will it take?
duration.text: Your first class might only be 30-45 minutes. As you learn more poses, your practice will naturally grow longer and, eventually, reach to around 60-90 minutes or more.

items.note: Most shalas have mats to borrow, but feel free to bring yours
Form-fitting so the teacher can see your alignment
You will sweat. Some shalas offer showers
We don't drink during practice. Hydrate before and after

important.title: Important
items: Practice on an empty stomach (no food 2-3 hours before)
Remove jewelry, watches, and strong fragrances
Leave your phone outside the room

findShala.title: Find a shala
findShala.text: The best way to learn Ashtanga is with a teacher in person. Look for shalas that offer Mysore-style classes.

items.a: Traditionally, early morning (Brahma Muhurta) is considered the best time for practice, the mind is calmer, prana flows more freely, and there are fewer distractions. It also leaves the rest of your day free. That said, some shalas offer afternoon or evening classes too.

items.q: How flexible do I need to be?
items.a: You don't need to be flexible at all. Flexibility comes from practice. You start exactly where you are.

items.q: What if I can't do a pose?
items.a: Every pose has modifications. Your teacher will adapt the practice to you and, with practice, you'll build strength and flexibility over time.

aParts.before: Traditionally, ashtangis practice 6 days a week, resting on
aParts.after: . You can see benefits from practicing 2-3 times a week.

items.a: Yes, once you've learned the sequence from a teacher. You can also find recorded led classes and online shalas.

items.q: I have an injury. Can I still practice?
items.a: Usually yes, with modifications. Always tell your teacher before class.

items.q: Can I skip ahead if I know some poses?

aParts.before: We always start from the beginning and practice in order. Repetition builds discipline and prepares your body. Some poses act as
aParts.after: that ensure you're ready before progressing.

items.q: I learned this differently elsewhere. What should I do?
items.a: Follow the teacher in the room. You can ask if something feels very different, but generally you respect the teachings in your presence.

items.q: Do I need a certified or authorised teacher?
items.a: No. Many wonderful teachers haven't had the chance to study in Mysore. What matters is finding someone dedicated to the practice. You can also attend workshops with certified teachers globally.

cta.title: Ready to start?
cta.text: Find a Mysore class near you and just show up. Everyone was a beginner once.
